turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Come on, Drag. Lemme take a look.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: It'd go to your coconut head. You'd start getting ideas. Maybe even pass right out.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: A cold drink.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: A cold drink? You mean one cold drink? To feast yore starvin' fishy l'il eyes on The Picture? A true vision of Paradise itself? With two of the angels right there in plain sight a- friskin' round with mah boy?

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: A cold drink? Okay?

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Well --- okay. It's a deal. One cold drink, if'n you please. In advance. One chilly bottle right here in mah hot l'il hand... That goes for the rest of you mullet-heads, too.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: That's my baby.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: He's gonna be awright.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Somebody say somethin'?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: I didn't say nothin', Boss.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Well, whatta we got here?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: A Lucas Jackson.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Oh we got our sources... Tearing the heads off... what was it... gumball machines? What kind of thing is that for a grown man?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Well, you know. Small town, not much to do in the evenings. Mostly it was settling up old scores.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Whatta you so happy about?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: I just always did like truck rides.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Plumb busted out. Looks like the hard road finally got to Mister Lucas War Hero.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Back at it in the mornin'. Just need a little nap...

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Course not. He ain't in the box 'cause a the joke played on him. He's there 'cause he back sassed a Free Man. They got their rules and we ain't got nothing to do with that. Woulda probably happened to him sooner or later, to a complainer like him. He's gotta learn the rules same as anybody else.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Yeah, those poor old guards need all the help they can get.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: You tryin' to say somethin'?

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Slow down, man. They ain't passing out medals for slinging dirt.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: I thought you knew, boy... they sentenced me by the mile.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Man, this here Newmeat parking meter bandit thing what calls itself Luke don't know nuthin' 'bout nuthin'.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: But damn if he don't look like a fat old Dragline.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Maybe he's been chain-ganging too long.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Long enough to see redhots come and redhots go.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Lucille? Where do you get that?

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: That'sa Lucille, you mullet head! Any girl so innocent and built like that gotta be named Lucille.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Innocent?

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Shut your mouth 'bout my Lucille.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Your Lucille? Man, you better put them glasses back on and take a look at yourself.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Boy. You jus' asking to be handled!

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Whatta you mean, forget it?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Stop beatin', man. You ain't doin' nobody no good.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: I'm gonna kill you, you go on...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: That's what you're gonna have to do.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Nuthin'! A handfull of nuthin'!  You stupid mullet-head. He beat you with nuthin'! Just like today when he kept coming back at me.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Nuthin' can be a pretty cool hand.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Cool Hand Luke.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Hey, buddy. Take it easy. You're making me look bad.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: The man wants speed, let's give it to him. Ram it in and break it off. Go hard. Shag it.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: They don't know iff'n to smile, spit or swallow.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: They ain't never seen a bull gang before.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Where'd the road go?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: That's it. That's the end.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Why'd you have to say fifty? Why not thirty-five or thirty-nine?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Fifty's a nice round number.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Damn, Luke. What's the matter with you? what's the matter with me?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Nothin' to worry about. We got a deadlock on that mullet.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: What did I do? Stole and tole lies. I loved mah neighbor and his wife, but what did I do to deserve this lunatic to come in mah happy home and beat me outa hard earned bread.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: We got it locked in the sock.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Yeah, I know. But what we gotta do first is stretch that l'il ol' belly of yours -- git it all strained out, in fightin' shape, like a barrage balloon.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: You ol' sack of guts. I had a belly like yours, we wouldn't have nothin' to worry about.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: 'Atsa sign I got me an affectionate nature.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Like an elephant.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Us elephants may be a lil slow, like in makin' love, but you give us a coupla three days to really get with it an' man -- stand back!

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Look at Him go. Bam! Bam!

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Knock it off, Luke! You cain't talk about Him that way.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Sure do... that's why we didn't bet with the Navy.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Oh, that's mah darlin' Luke. Grins like a baby and bites like a 'gator.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Don't hit me no more, Boss! Don't hit me! I'll do anythin' you say but just don't hit me! Oh Luke. You are an original, you truly are. You really fooled them.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Foolin', Hell! I would have eaten that dirt for them. They coulda used my head for a shovel and a my face for a broom... They just never did get a piece of my mind.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: And all the time you was plannin' on runnin' again.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Whoee, it's cold. Wisht I had somethin' to eat. Bread, grits, beans even. Soon's we get to my house, we're gonna have us one big meal and then I'm gonna show you some farm girls that...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: We ain't goin' nowhere.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: What you talkin' about, Luke? We're together, you and me, just like always. Now the thing we gotta work out is how to get Koko outa there and then the Terrible Trio be all complete again. Man, this old Free World ain't gonna know which ear to stand on.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Yeah, well, you and Koko kin handle it without me.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: What you mean, Luke?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: I've done enough world-shakin' for a while. You do the rest for me. Send me a postcard about it.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: But, Luke...

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Take it easy, Drag.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Luke. Where you goin?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: On my own.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: But what am I gonna do all by myself?  Oh if'n I hadn't lost mah head. I only had two more years to go. But when I saw you tearin' down with that truck... But you right Luke. We oughta split up. Be safer for us both.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Is that your answer, Old Man? You're a hardcase too, ain't you?

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Luke, are you alright?... They got us, boy. They're out there thicker'n flies. Bosses and dogs and sheriffs and more guns than I ever seen in my life. We don't have a chance, Luke... They caught up with me right after we split up and they was aimin' to kill you, Luke. But I got 'em to promise if you give up peaceful, they wouldn't even whip you this time.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Do we even get our same bunks back?

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Why sure, Luke. I mean I didn't talk to them about that. But why not? They're reasonable, Luke. Hell, we only been gone a coupla hours.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: You don't understand a thing, do you, Drag?

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Luke, you got to listen to me. All you got to do is just give up nice and quiet, just play it cool.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Like I always do?

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Thass right. Just play it...

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: Dragline gives out the names here. You'll get yours when he figures you out.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Maybe we oughta call you No-Ears. You don't listen much, do you, boy?

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: Not a liar. You just have a common -- and likable -- tendency toward exaggeration.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: He's the champeen hog-gut of this camp. Hell, I seen him eat ten choc'lat bars and seven cold drinks in fifteen minutes. He kin eat busted bottles and rusty nails, any damn thing. If you'd so kindly oblige as to let me cut off your yankee head, he'd even eat that.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Nobody kin eat fifty eggs.

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: You just said he could eat anything.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: You ever eat fifty eggs?

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Koko, write down their names, don't just make marks.

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: One rule! No throwing up. He throws up, you forfeit everything.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: You ever see mah boy throw up? Shut your mouth and put up your money!

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: He peels the eggs himself. That's understood.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: You jus' may be great at hangin' paper around the big cities, but us country boys is not entirely brainless. When it comes to the law, nothin' is understood.

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: Thirty-nine... forty... forty-one... forty-two...

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Come on, boy, come on, darlin'. You kin do her. Just let that ol' belly sag and enjoy itself. Stay loose, buddy. Eight more, between you and everlasting glory. Little ol' eggs, pigeon eggs, that's all, fish eggs practically.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: All right now: get mad at them eggs. Eat it there boy! Bite it! Gnaw on it!

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: Forty-five.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: What's the writing say?

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: Dear Boys. Playing it cool. Wish you were here. Love, Cool Hand Luke.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Oh my. Oh my... Give it back here!

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: That ole box collapse and fall apart before Luke calls quits.

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: Your Luke's got more guts than brains.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Oh Lord!

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: That fool. That damn fool.

turns.speaker: DRAGLINE
turns.text: Oh mah baby Luke.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: A bunch. Must be halfa dozen Newmeat.

turns.speaker: GAMBLER
turns.text: No more than five. For a cold drink.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Bet! Babalugats, bet here!

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Man! It's gonna be one hot muther today.

turns.speaker: GAMBLER
turns.text: Bears gonna be walkin' the road today.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Man, it's so hot.

turns.speaker: GAMBLER
turns.text: Gettin' up, Carr.

turns.speaker: GAMBLER
turns.text: Ana paira ninas. Koko's the brains.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Cuter.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: I'm in.

turns.speaker: GAMBLER
turns.text: Ace calls. Here we go.  King-five gets a tray for no help.  Paira ninas gets a Jack.  Ana man with the ace gets... slop in the face... Ninas up.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Cuter again.

turns.speaker: GAMBLER
turns.text: Call.

turns.speaker: GAMBLER
turns.text: I gotta believe. Out!  Now they're rollin'.  King-five-four gets an eight.  Pair'a nines with a Jack gets a four. Ninas still up.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Cuter.

turns.speaker: GAMBLER
turns.text: Man, you play like a kokonut. You got to call him at least.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: I know he's got a paira kings. He don't have to stick 'em in my ear.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Oh no, man! Not on this hot muther.

turns.speaker: GAMBLER
turns.text: All the bears gonna be walking today.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Man Oh Man.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: That is one mean lady. Bet her husband spends one day a week shooting milkmen.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Kick a buck.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Damn.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Back a buck.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Kick a buck.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Yeah, found one in this supermarket, keys in the ignition.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Well, how far didya get?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Fat mile'n a half. Hit this red light, highway patrol pulls up alongside.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Picture's a phoney... Cost me a week's pay.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: A phoney? Whatta you mean, a phoney?

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: But -- but --

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: That's all there was. Listen. Open your eyes. Stop beatin' it. And stop feedin' off me. Now get out of the way. Give me some air.

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: Koko, why don't you let one of these Newmeats take your broom for today?

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Hell, no. I ain't goin' down in the ditch.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: You can't switch 'round jobs, anyway. I figured he knew that.

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: You can't expect him to learn everything the first day. Hopefully it's taught him a very valuable lesson.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: You think you've been working hard. This muther'll break your back.

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: This is a big day for the guards. They get to remind us who's boss.

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: One, two, three...

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: He's gonna lose a finger eating eggs like that.

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: Stop that.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: How about you tryin' to make me?

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: Oh for...

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: He'll never make it.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: He doesn't know when to give in. They'll kill him.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Give in? That's our Luke out there.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: I don't see no sign of guts in you.

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: No. No chains either.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: You ain't man enough to wear them!

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: But you're dog enough. Maybe they'll let you sleep outside the box near your master.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: Big deal paper hanger! Hell, anyone who can write can pass fifty-sixty dollar checks. Like breakin' open a piggy bank.

turns.speaker: SOCIETY RED
turns.text: You've been having bad luck with masters, haven't you? Your last one left you when the cops came... and now Luke. You should complain to the S.P.C.A.

turns.speaker: KOKO
turns.text: You phony creep!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Excuse me, but would you mind explaining why you're watching the lady upstairs?

turns.speaker: RUBEN
turns.text: None of your fucking business.

turns.speaker: RUBEN
turns.text: I hate this...

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Only kidding!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Now look what you did.

turns.speaker: RUBEN
turns.text: What did I do?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: You threatened to drive her downtown.  She has agoraphobia.

turns.speaker: RUBEN
turns.text: Fear of what...

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Open space.  She hasn't been out of this apartment in three years.  I didn't used to think it was real...

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: It's good medicine.

turns.speaker: RUBEN
turns.text: A little homeopathic cure for the willies.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Where were you?  Don't tell me. It's just under seventy, right?  The sun is strong but the air is dry and fresh...

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Would you please get your hands off my face, Tallulah?  What happened to the newspaper?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I got it myself... I couldn't wait.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Well!  Aren't we the daring one? What's morbid and ghastly enough in the news to make Doctor Helen set foot outside her door?  The antenna is gone off her car again.  I had no music, all the way to the market.  Let me find a garage for it?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I've told you:  I can't afford to garage it.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Are you kidding?  You buy enough gourmet junk every week... most of which <u>rots</u>... to garage a fleet of stretch limos.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I had the dream again.  And I got another call.  This time he spoke.  He said "You and me, you and me."

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: A little heavy breathing is what most of us yearn for.  <u>Forget</u> it.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: He whispered, but it was <u>him</u>!  I know it was him!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: He can't phone you unless the warden gets an okay from you.  Did you give him an approval?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Andy?  When a three-year-old says there's a monster under the bed, you don't say 'forget it'.  You look under the bad.  I'm three years old.  Call the prison.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Oh God.  I'm really crazy.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: When was the last time you washed your hair?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Monsieur Andy, disapproves of my coiffure?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Monsieur Andy can <u>smell</u> your coiffure.  And guess what else?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Cellulite.  What do you say I blindfold you and take you to the gym.  Aerobics with housewives...

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Andy?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: You parked right behind him.  The one I noticed earlier.  I didn't say anything, I thought he'd leave. Just take a look.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Oh my God!  Help!  HE'S READING A NEWSPAPER!

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: But earlier, he was staring up here.  <u>Please</u>, Andy.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Okay.  You win.  'Dirty Harry' coming up.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Oh, God.  I must have looked horrible.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: No, dear.  You're at your best with a bag in front of your face.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I want to die.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I wouldn't.  He'll be back.  If you want him.  The cute brutal type with handcuffs.  Very sexy.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: What?  What'd I do?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Reminded me that I used to be attractive.  That men used to want me...

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: You <u>slut</u>!  No sexy young cop for you unless you shampoo your hair.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: When are you going to call them?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: About what?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I can't, Andy.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Then, why don't you just die.  I'm going.  They'll find your body years later, the old recluse lady, she ate cat food, ten years of the New York Times, unread, piled on top of the unread mail, the TV still on.  Make up your mind.  Live or die.  I'll get coffee.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: None of you know anything about it. Now go.  And Andy, if you persist in playing doctor, leave, with them.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I'm the only friend you've got, darling, and I don't intend to stop doing what I think is good for us.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Get out!  All of you!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: The moon is up, my night to howl. Will you be okay?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Oh, God, I forget.  Yes.  Yes.  You go.  Poor thing, you ought to get out.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Look out for her.  She's tougher than you think.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: You're fired.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I know.  Do come and meet your guest.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Sorry, Luv.  I've got a date.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: You've got a date right <u>here</u>, Andy. This has got to...

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: It's almost six.  And guess what? Hall likes me bathed and shaved.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Stop acting like a silly little fag!

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: You bastard!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: But </u>alive</u>!

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Where have you <u>been</u>?  What happened to your wallet?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Hal has it.

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: Investigators Halloran and Goetz.  I apologize for Goetz, he's a firehouse dog.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I'm okay.  I really kind of enjoyed it.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Are you staying long?  Shall I shut the door?  Make your coffee?  Make the beds?

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: You talked to me.  Do you remember?

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: We'll get the paramedics...

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Oh, God, uniforms, more stress. Let her sleep.  It's a self-limiting: she hyperventilates till she passes out, then her breathing goes back to normal, and she wakes up singing like a lark.  We know, don't we, Princess?  Give her a couple of hours.  I know about this.

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: Tell her we're sorry we bothered her.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Hey, no.  Leave those here.  If you really want her help.  I mean if you really do, leave them.  Let her see them.  I'll see they're safe...

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: She just got to sleep.  Do you have to tell her about it now?

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: Tell her about <u>what</u>?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Gaahhd!  What a <u>cop</u>!  You busted me!  The new one, in the Marina.  She has a police radio scanner. It's always on.  She turns it off, and then she has to turn it on again.  She's obsessed.  She can't not listen to it, but she can't listen to it, so she makes me listen to it.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Yes.  Without question.

turns.speaker: ATTORNEY
turns.text: Without question?  He only scored 40 percent, four out of ten criteria?  Couldn't another expert say he <u>flunked</u> the sexual sadist test?  What curve are you marking on, Doctor?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: The test criteria are only part of what we look at in evaluating subjects.

turns.speaker: ATTORNEY
turns.text: Only part.  What else?  What did you think of his claim that he tied this girl to the tree and set fire to her because Joan of Arc told him to do it.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: He was lying.

turns.speaker: ATTORNEY
turns.text: 'Lying.  He was lying.'  I asked you what you thought, not what he did.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I thought he was lying.

turns.speaker: ATTORNEY
turns.text: You said, first, he was lying.  How do you know that, Doctor?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Because people who are suffering from aural hallucinations hear voices in both ears.  Daryll Lee told me that Joan of Arc always appeared beside him on his left side and spoke softly in his left ear.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: He took pains to hide his actions because he knew they were morally wrong.  He was not acting on mad impulse.  He was sane and acting out a pattern he carefully followed every time.

turns.speaker: ATTORNEY
turns.text: What pattern was that?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: The same as the first time...

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: The first two murders.

turns.speaker: ATTORNEY
turns.text: What first two murders.  We don't know about them here, do we?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: He told me he had done two others just like it.

turns.speaker: ATTORNEY
turns.text: When was that?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: When he was seventeen.

turns.speaker: ATTORNEY
turns.text: And you believed him when he told you he had done that.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Yes.  I believed him.

turns.speaker: CONRAD
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: Inspector Halloran.  Homicide. You were supposed to contact a Peter Kurten?

turns.speaker: CONRAD
turns.text: I was?  How you spell that?

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: Cut the crap.  You got a sheet the length of my arm...

turns.speaker: CONRAD
turns.text: I never hurt nobody...

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: Shut up -- I'm talking.  You got felony breaking and entering, burglary, felonious...

turns.speaker: CONRAD
turns.text: I never carried a gun!

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: You don't listen very good.  This break in -- I can call it a felony -- three strikes, and you got about sixteen strikes already, and you're in jail for the rest of your life, no parole.  Or I could see it gets forgotten.

turns.speaker: CONRAD
turns.text: You get me out first.

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: Doesn't work that way.  You had your chance, now fuck yourself...

turns.speaker: CONRAD
turns.text: Tell me what you want me to say. Anything.

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: You were going to make a delivery to Peter Kurten for Daryll Lee Cullum.  I want Kurten's phone number.

turns.speaker: CONRAD
turns.text: I don't have it...

turns.speaker: CONRAD
turns.text: Wait... wait... I already called him, I threw it away.

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: You already made the delivery?

turns.speaker: CONRAD
turns.text: No, that's still in my jacket I was wearing.  We were supposed to meet on the docks, that number 47 wharf, 10 o'clock Friday.  He's gonna hand me 500 bucks.

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: What Friday?

turns.speaker: CONRAD
turns.text: What day is this?  In jail you lose track.  This week.  Friday.

turns.speaker: RUBEN
turns.text: Then you get your ass outta here, I don't wanta see you again...

turns.speaker: CONRAD
turns.text: I brought a present for the lady, there.  I'm looking for her, to give her the present...

turns.speaker: RUBEN
turns.text: You break into her apartment to deliver a gift?  Where is it?

turns.speaker: CONRAD
turns.text: The door was open, swear to God, I'm just looking for her when you come charging up the stairs...

turns.speaker: RUBEN
turns.text: Where is it?

turns.speaker: CONRAD
turns.text: I'm trying to tell you.  It's on the lady's pillow...

turns.speaker: CONRAD
turns.text: Daryll Lee Cullum, he wrote that book, he wanted the lady to have it.  They won't let him send it to her, so I'm getting out, he asks me to deliver it in person, he says, put it on her pillow.  It has all about how he tried to kill her.

turns.speaker: RUBEN
turns.text: He told you she was loaded, any- thing you could steal you could keep, Conrad?  You bought yourself a return ticket to Quentin, breaking and entering.

turns.speaker: CONRAD
turns.text: The door was already open...

turns.speaker: RUBEN
turns.text: We know...  Send the book to evidence...

turns.speaker: CONRAD
turns.text: She's supposed to have it.

turns.speaker: RUBEN
turns.text: She don't want it.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Hello, Daryll Lee.

turns.speaker: DARYLL
turns.text: You read my book which as you know, hit the stands a couple of weeks ago.  You read it yet.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: What book?

turns.speaker: DARYLL
turns.text: I sent it by private courier, he didn't give it to you?  That son of a gun...!

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I'll look for it, Daryll Lee.

turns.speaker: DARYLL
turns.text: Bet you never figured I'd follow in your footsteps.  It's real well- written.  You should read it -- you're in it.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I will.  I'll call you, Daryll, and talk to you about it after I've read it.  Right now I have a question... Peter Kurten.

turns.speaker: DARYLL
turns.text: Kurten!  Is he bothering you?  I told that son I'd send him what he wanted if he leave you alone.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Ah ha.  What did he want?

turns.speaker: DARYLL
turns.text: Something personal.  Is he bothering you?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I don't know.  I'd like to know where he is.

turns.speaker: DARYLL
turns.text: Listen, you want my advice?  Steer clear.  He's writing me he's gonna finish 'my unfinished symphony.' He's gonna give me $550 for some of my cum, he says he's in a position to see that I will be immortal if he has some of my spunk.  I'm offended.  Right away I smell <u>freak</u>.  Writin' about him and me and <u>you</u> bein' joined and he's gonna finish my <u>symphony</u>?  I didn't care for his drift.  I sent some liquid soap in a sandwich baggie with a message from Jesus to mend his ways.  You hear I found Jesus?  And what's funny is, now I don't mind bein' inside.  If I was out, even Born Again, I'd probably get restless again.  It's maybe better I stay here, what do you think?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I think whatever is best for you, Daryll.  And maybe you're right, that's the place.

turns.speaker: DARYLL
turns.text: You come and visit.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Where did you send the message to Peter Kurten?

turns.speaker: DARYLL
turns.text: Damn!  I gave that to Conrad, too! That guy!  I told Conrad deliver to Kurten and keep the 500 bucks in return for getting my book to you.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: How was Conrad supposed to find Kurten?

turns.speaker: DARYLL
turns.text: Conrad has the phone number. Conrad, where is he?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: In jail.

turns.speaker: DARYLL
turns.text: That Klutz.  They send him back here, I'll kick his ass good.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Hi.  It's your worst student, Peter Foley -- how do you grade me now, Doctor?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Who was the man in the basement?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You like that action?  Didn't that cop on TV look <u>solemn</u>?  The guy in the basement doesn't matter, anyway, just another lonely heart.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Where are you, Peter?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: <u>You</u> thought I was going to do Ted Bundy next, so you sent your partner...

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What was that?  What am I hearing? The sound of an epiphany, a sudden blinding insight?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: It's Daryll Lee Cullum, isn't it?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Mm-hmm.  I can't get to you.  You have to come to me.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: You know I can't do that.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Oh, I think you will.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: For God's sake Peter, leave her out of it.  You don't want her, you want me.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I need her; she's a cop.  I have to kill a cop, and then...

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: You've been perfect.  Don't spoil the symmetry -- you have to have a male cop.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I don't care -- she's a cop.  That's the important thing.  Cop-ness, not sex-ness.  It won't be perfect, but it'll be good.
